qas.question: UI redress attack or User Interface redress attack is also known as what?
What is a malicious technique in which an attacker tricks the user into clicking on a button or link?
Where are the clicks meant for the top level page routed?
Where would a password typed on a seemingly authetic webpage be directed?

answers.text: into an invisible frame controlled by the attacker

qas.question: How istricking the user accomplished in clickjacking?

answers.text: using multiple transparent or opaque layers

qas.question: What is intended to be hijacked through a page overlay?
What else can be hijacked through UI redress?
What part of a webpage is meant to collect keystrokes?

plausible_answers.text: This is done using multiple transparent or opaque layers

qas.question: Why can the user not see the other page used by the attacker?
Where is are the passwords and information stored by the attacker?
What is avoiding a UI redress attack called?
How are clicks routed back to the top level page?

plausible_answers.text: a combination of stylesheets, iframes, buttons and text boxes

qas.question: How is an legitimate webpage created?
What is another name for hijacking keystrokes?
Where is a user redirected to after putting in their password?

context: <a0_0><a1_0><b10_0>Clickjacking<b10_0/><a1_0/><a0_0/>, also known as "<b13_0>UI redress attack<b13_0/> or User Interface redress attack", is a malicious technique in which an attacker tricks a user into clicking on a button or link on another webpage while the user intended to click on the top level page. <b8_0>This is done <a4_0>using <b11_0>multiple transparent or opaque layers<b11_0/><b8_0/><a4_0/>. The attacker is basically "hijacking" the clicks meant for the top level page and routing them to <a2_0><b14_0>some other irrelevant page<b14_0/><a2_0/>, most likely owned by someone else. A similar technique can be used to hijack <b6_0>keystrokes<b6_0/>. Carefully drafting <b12_0>a combination of stylesheets, iframes, buttons and <b7_0>text boxes<b12_0/><b7_0/>, a user can be led into believing that they are typing <b5_0>the password or other information<b5_0/> on some authentic webpage while it is being channeled <a3_0>into <b9_0>an invisible frame<b9_0/> controlled by the attacker<a3_0/>.
